Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Extinction and Diversification Dynamics of Archosauria Through Early Mesozoic Climate Crises
Award.AbstractNarration:
Two mass extinctions occurred early in the Mesozoic Era shortly after dinosaurs appeared, and multiple lines of evidence suggest that dramatic global climate change events were contributing factors. This project will investigate the response of the extinct relatives of birds and crocodilians (the Archosauria) to these episodes. The primary objectives of this study are to analyze the evolutionary relationships of fossil archosaurs, and use these evolutionary relationships as a framework to investigate how archosaur respiratory anatomy and body temperature regulation changed after the extinctions at the end of the Triassic Period and during the Early Jurassic Epoch. The study will test the hypothesis that global warming events initiated evolutionary changes in respiratory anatomy and contributed to currently unexplained patterns of extinction and diversification of extinct archosaurs, including dinosaurs. This research will provide insight into the ways that vertebrate communities on land respond to rapid changes in climate, and may help to predict which species will experience an increased risk of extinction during modern climate change. This research will provide multiple opportunities for undergraduate training. In addition, educational materials based on the results will be distributed to educators at secondary and higher education levels, as well as disseminated in the form of scientific papers and presentations at professional meetings.

Time-calibrated phylogenies of Archosauria will be estimated using both parsimony analyses of morphology and combined-evidence Bayesian approaches to phylogeny reconstruction incorporating molecular sequence data from extant archosaurs. Character transformation rates for respiratory-related characters (e.g. postcranial skeletal pneumaticity) and non-respiratory characters will be modeled iteratively over a large sample of time-calibrated trees to account for uncertainty in phylogeny and chronology. Non-parametric statistics will be used to test for the presence of rate-shifts in respiratory character evolution surrounding the interval of extinctions and associated climate changes in the early Mesozoic Era.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Archosauria is a group of organisms that dominated terrestrial Mesozoic ecosystems and includes living birds and crocodiles, their most recent common ancestor, and all of its descendants, including non-avian dinosaurs and pterosaurs. These organisms are characterized by skeletal pneumaticity—outpocketings of the respiratory tract that can invade bones of the skull, vertebrae, ribs, or limb skeleton and create air spaces within them. Many studies have speculated on the original functional significance of archosaur skeletal pneumaticity, often proposing relationships to respiratory efficiency, temperature regulation, and/or body size, but the adaptive value of skeletal pneumaticity to the Permian and Triassic terrestrial organisms that first evolved elaborate pneumatic systems remains a mystery. Interestingly, different lineages of archosaurs that evolved distinct pneumatic systems in different regions of the skeleton survived two mass extinction events associated with catastrophic changes in climate that occurred at the ends of the Triassic and Early Jurassic, while many archosaur lineages without these pneumatic systems went extinct. The primary goals of this study were to generate a large evolutionary tree of archosaurs, create new quantitative methods for measuring rates of morphological change related to skeletal pneumaticity, and to use statistics to test hypotheses regarding the potential relationship between skeletal pneumaticity and Mesozoic climate events.

Mapping the pneumatic features we observed on the evolutionary tree of archosaurs showed that newly evolved pneumatic morphologies often first appeared following abrupt climatic changes associated with major vertebrate extinction events. Our new methods allowed us to create time series for evolutionary rates of change in pneumatic systems, and these time series were significantly correlated with proxy datasets for atmospheric oxygenation (the rate of change of oxygen in the atmosphere) and atmospheric temperature. These promising results have led to new methodological questions and solutions, and our work testing hypotheses regarding the rates of change in skeletal pneumaticity across Triassic-Early Jurassic climatic events is ongoing.

The impacts of the current changing climate on ecosystems and agriculture, as well as the potential impacts on human health are potentially dire, and the industrialized world may induce further catastrophic events affecting the climate and modern biota in the future. Paleontological studies seeking quantitative explanations for biotic responses to climate change have been challenging owing to imperfect and uneven preservation of the fossil record in deep time, among other factors. The methodological advances of this study will provide new tools to researchers investigating this problem, make a significant contribution to the understanding of past biotic responses to greenhouse conditions, and suggest new directions for research on ecological change during modern climate change. The current results imply a narrative account of climatically-induced extinction and evolutionary response that can be explained in plain terms: the world quickly became very hot and it became difficult for organisms to breathe efficiently. Animals either adapted accordingly or went extinct.
